channel.title: Disk Image
channel.description: Hello, I was wondering if there was a way to create an installation disk image for Windows XP, just by the Hard Drive image. Like let's say I have a fresh install of XP with nothing other than the absolute basic requirements to run it, explorer, all that good stuff. How would I create an installation boot image so I can install it on a different computer?

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Unhandled:

Yeah dd copys the hard disk byte for byte, so that would have moved all the partition information, boot sector, etc I think.

Depends if you did it on the entire hard drive (eg, sda) or on one partition (eg, sda1). You should be able to do it on one partition and move it around to different hard drives.

Read full topic

item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

WEll I took the code you posted, adjusted as necessary(for some reason there’s this 4 mb partition at the beginning of my HDD and I can’t get rid of it, so it thinks that’s the first partition) and then the 30 GB unformatted section somehow disappeared, so my HDD is 30 GB smaller, and then I tried it with a 10 GB formatted partition and the same thing happened. SO i did some reasearch and came across using the floppys as a sort of bootable media for installing XP, but I can’t try it until at least tomorrow.

Read full topic

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Here is a good-looking tutorial: http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/linux-newbie-8/learn-the-dd-command-362506/

Basically, to dump a partition to a file:
dd if=/dev/hda1 of=/path/to/file

and to put it back on, you guessed it
dd if=/path/to/file of=/dev/hda1

Of course, instead of doing one partition you may want to do a whole drive:
dd if=/dev/hda of=/path/to/file
and back
dd if=/path/to/file of=/dev/hda

That is assuming the hard drive is hda, and the partition is hda1.

Read full topic

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Sorry if this is a stupid question, buit I’ve been going for about a week and a half without any sort of sleep. And I guess I"m just not getting it. So I use dd to put the image on the partition of my Hard drive. Does the Partition have to be blank, or can it already be formatted to ntfs? How do I copy the windows image onto the disk? DO I use Partition Image, or is there a better application you could suggest?

Read full topic

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You would use dd to put the image back on.

item.title: Disk Image

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t think you understood what I was saying, dd is the program you are looking for to make a disk image.

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

WEll I want to dual boot my system with Xp and Linux, because alot of the applications I"m using are windows specific, and I have yet to find a Linux equivalent. And I have an 8 year old box that has XP on it, and Since I have an ATI graphics card, wine is not making the full potential of the card.

Read full topic

item.title: Disk Image
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You could use dd, on a linux distro or live cd.

But unless the computers are almost identical in hardware it may not work, because drivers would be different and the way the BIOS lets windows boot will be different. (ie, you installed with PATA mode, but the other computer has SATA, or vice-versa)

Read full topic
